verses.text: Save, LORD, for the godly one is gone; the faithful have vanished from among the children of man.
verses.comment: The psalmist begins with a lament for the decline of the faithful, paralleling the moral decay also described in Micah 7:2. This sets up a context of spiritual crisis, inviting prayer for divine intervention.

verses.text: Everyone speaks lies to his neighbor; with flattering lips and a double heart they speak.
verses.comment: The imagery of 'flattering lips' and 'double heart' exposes hypocrisy and insincerity among people, a perennial theme in wisdom literature. See also Psalm 55:21 for similar warnings.

verses.text: May the LORD cut off all flattering lips, the tongue that makes great boasts,
verses.comment: Using direct language for divine judgment, the psalmist calls for an end to deceitful and arrogant speech. This reflects the need for God's justice and the purification of the community, anticipating themes found in the letter of James (James 3:5-10).

verses.text: who say, 'By our tongue we will prevail; our lips are with us—who is master over us?'
verses.comment: Here, arrogance reaches its peak: people believe their words alone make them powerful. This displays a rebellion against God’s rightful authority, an idea echoed in the prophets.

verses.text: 'Because the poor are plundered, because the needy groan, I will now arise,' says the LORD; 'I will place him in the safety for which he longs.'
verses.comment: God responds personally to the suffering of the poor and oppressed. The LORD’s intervention to 'arise' is a repeated motif in the Psalms (see Psalm 9:18), ultimately fulfilled in Christ's incarnation and advocacy for the lowly.

verses.text: The words of the LORD are pure words, like silver refined in a furnace on the ground, purified seven times.
verses.comment: God’s speech stands in stark contrast to the lies of men, described as perfectly pure. The number seven signifies completeness. God's promise never fails, foreshadowing the trustworthiness of the Word made flesh (John 1:14).

verses.text: You, O LORD, will keep them; you will guard us from this generation forever.
verses.comment: God’s faithful protection is eternal, safeguarding His people from evil. The idea of divine preservation goes beyond a single moment, suggesting the stewardship of the faithful community across generations.

verses.text: On every side the wicked prowl, as vileness is exalted among the children of man.
verses.comment: The psalm closes with a recognition of ongoing evil—even when God protects, moral decay continues outwardly. This tension pushes the reader to long for the deeper, complete restoration only fulfilled in the coming of the Messiah.
